1.30.text:
Alice: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Alice.

5.72.text: Alice: So, it's nearly exam time again.

8.76.text:
And the subject of today's show is how to
prepare well for an exam.

12.82.text: Rob: I've got some great tips, actually, Alice.

14.95.text:
Alice: Have you really? Can you remind me
what grades you got at school?

22.31.text: Alice: So, you didn't get very good grades.

25.52.text:
Rob: I probably should've started revising
earlier.

28.54.text: But my learning strategies were very good.

32.52.text: When you revise for an exam you study information you learned before.

36.92.text: OK, Rob, I'd love to hear more about your learning strategies, but first here's today's quiz question for you.

44.22.text: What's the word for a system, such as use of special poems or rhymes to help you remember something?

51.38.text:
Is it ... a) pneumatics
b) mnemonics

58.06.text: Rob: I'll go for b) mnemonics.

60.90.text:
Alice: Well, we'll find out whether you got
the answer right or not later on in the show.

65.32.text: Now, according to current scientific research, some study methods popular with students aren't actually very effective.

72.98.text:
Rob: Don't tell me – putting your textbook
under your pillow at night doesn't work.

77.68.text: Alice: Did you try doing that, Rob?

79.20.text: Rob: Yes, I did, but without much success.

82.00.text: Maybe I was using the wrong kind of pillow?!

84.13.text:
Alice: Well, let's talk about more conventional
methods than the book-under-the-pillow one.

89.75.text:
These include summarising, highlighting or
underlining text to help you remember it...

95.87.text: I do love a pack of highlighting pens, though.

98.15.text:
Rob: Oh yes, me too. And actually highlighting
text was one of my top tips.

103.83.text:
But I used to get so absorbed with the highlighting
I'm not sure I was actually learning anything useful.

109.09.text: My notebooks were works of art, though!

111.14.text:
Alice: Yes, and that's the point made by John
Dunlosky,

114.81.text:
Professor of Psychology at Kent State University
in the US,

119.18.text:
who says that you need to do more than just
highlight information.

123.24.text:
You need to test yourself on it. Let's hear
from him now.

127.98.text: John Dunlosky: Students who can basically test themselves or try to retrieve material from their memory

133.62.text: are going to learn that material in the long run a lot better.

136.60.text: So for instance maybe you start by reading a textbook using your favourite highlighter and favourite colours,

142.26.text: but then you go back and make flashcards of all the critical concepts

145.81.text:
and instead of just rereading those, you basically
try to test yourselves on them.

153.80.text:
So he says trying to memorise the material
isn't enough.

157.98.text:
You need to do something with it, for example,
making flashcards of critical

162.78.text:
or important – concepts and then testing yourself on
them.

166.07.text:
Alice: By repeatedly testing yourself on something,
you strengthen the pathways between neurons

171.38.text: or nerve cells – in the brain.

173.72.text:
And the more often you do this, the easier
it becomes to retrieve information.

178.32.text: Rob: And retrieve means to get something back.

182.15.text: When you repeatedly test yourself over a longer period of time

186.10.text: for example, over months or weeks

188.52.text: this is called distributed practice – and psychologists believe this is a very effective way to learn.

194.62.text:
Rob: It sounds like hard work, though, doesn't
it?

199.45.text: which means to try and learn lots of information in a short period of time.

204.41.text: For example, the night before the exam.

207.99.text: We don't cram to learn other things – like music or dancing, or football or language learning.

214.84.text:
It's far more effective to join a conversation
class and practise speaking every week than

219.90.text:
to practise for hours in front of the mirror
the night before your oral exam!

225.81.text:
In fact, I used to sing irregular French verbs
to myself,

229.15.text: every day in the shower for weeks before my French exam,

232.85.text: and that helped me remember them more easily.

235.48.text:
Alice: Excellent! Making different types of
associations with what you're trying to learn

240.14.text: for example, musical associations – is meant to be effective.

244.02.text:
Let's listen now to Professor Dunlovsky talking
about visual associations.

249.32.text:
John Dunlosky: I would encourage students
as they are reading to try and elaborate mentally

252.92.text:
using images, as they're reading, to kind
of develop a more vivid picture of what they're reading.

257.55.text:
Again, that'll help quite a bit for some kinds
of studies – maybe history and so forth

261.34.text:
and a little bit less so for more conceptual
studies.

264.32.text:
Rob: And if you elaborate on something, it
means you add more information

271.70.text:
Alice: So, creating mental pictures is useful
for some subjects – like history or languages.

277.86.text:
But conceptual subjects – ones based on
abstract ideas rather than things – like maths, for example

284.68.text: it might not be so easy to associate ideas with pictures.

288.34.text:
Rob: Now what about Albert Einstein? People
say he was a very visual thinker.

292.88.text: Alice: Well, you've got me there, Rob.

294.76.text:
I don't know the answer to that but I can
give you the answer to today's quiz question.

299.94.text: I asked: What's the word for a system, such as use of special poems or rhymes to help you remember something?

307.30.text:
Is it ... a) pneumatics, b) mnemonics or c)
hypnotics?

318.17.text: Alice: Well done! Research on mnemonics suggests they are a good strategy for learning certain kinds of things,

324.42.text:
like how to spell difficult
words.

326.56.text: For example, the first letters of this sentence:

330.14.text: "big elephants cause accidents under small elephants" spells "because".

337.18.text:
Now, do you think you can remember the words
we heard today, Rob?

353.64.text:
Alice: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute
English.

356.40.text: Remember to join us again soon!
